questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a laptop named Computer1 that runs Windows 10.
When in range, Computer1 connects automatically to a Wi-Fi network named Wireless1.
You need to prevent Computer1 from automatically connecting to Wireless1.
Solution: From the properties of the Wi-Fi adapter, you disable Link-Layer Topology Discovery Responder.
Does this meet the goal?
questions.answer_description:
Link-Layer Topology Discovery is used by their Network Map feature to display a graphical representation of the local area network (LAN) or wireless LAN
(WLAN), to which the computer is connected.
Reference:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_Layer_Topology_Discovery

questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory domain named contoso.com. The domain contains two computers named Computer1 and Computer2 that run Windows
10.
On Computer1, you need to run the Invoke-Command cmdlet to execute several PowerShell commands on Computer2.
What should you do first?

comments.content: Thanks :)

discussion.content:
The Enable-PSRemoting cmdlet configures the computer to receive PowerShell remote commands that are sent by using the WS-Management technology. WS-Management based PowerShell remoting is currently supported only on Windows platform.

PowerShell remoting is enabled by default on Windows Server platforms. You can use Enable-PSRemoting to enable PowerShell remoting on other supported versions of Windows and to re-enable remoting if it becomes disabled.

You have to run this command only one time on each computer that will receive commands. You do not have to run it on computers that only send commands. Because the configuration starts listeners to accept remote connections, it is prudent to run it only where it is needed.
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
I think the answer is A.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.
If like me you're like "what is invoke-command?" you can find a good intro at https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/learn/remoting/running-remote-commands?view=powershell-7.1

choices.D: On Computer2, add Computer1 to the Remote Management Users group
choices.B: From Active Directory, configure the Trusted for Delegation setting for the computer account of Computer2
choices.A: On Computer2, run the Enable-PSRemoting cmdlet
choices.C: On Computer1, run the New-PSSession cmdlet

choices.D: Windows Defender Firewall with Advanced Security

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your office has a dedicated wireless network for guests.
You plan to provide access cards that will have a QR code for guests. The QR code will link to a network configuration file stored on a publicly accessible website and provide the wireless network settings for Windows 10 devices.
Which tool should you use to create the configuration file and which file type should you use for the configuration file? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Solution is correct.
Alternate configuration is shown. These (alternate-)settings only apply if no DHCP is provided.
In segment 1: DHCP is enabled, so IP is assigned, 172.16.0.58
In segment 2: No DHCP is found, so alternate settings are applied, 172.16.0.10

comments.content: exactly !!! can't say better.

I did some quick research which seems to back up this answer. It sais: As @uSlackr has said, it is the configuration that Windows will use when DHCP is unavailable. This seems to imply that alternative configuration only applies, when the interface is set to automatic (dhcp) but a dhcp server is not found in the network.

discussion.content: I think it will 172.16.0.10 for both answers, because computer has static IP address already applied.

comments.content: I agree with you
It's not a static IP address. That's what i thought at first aswell. It's alternate address meaning it will only be used if DHCP is unavailable for some reason. See Perycles comment
The image show the "Altenate" tab.

This is not correct, if you assign a static IP to a host that hasnt been set to automatically detect and IP address from DHCP the static IP wont change.
I think the answer is 172.16.0.10 for both.

discussion.content: Both 172.16.0.10 because the address is a manually static address and will stay on that computer when you connect on segment1 or segment2. Its not getting an by DHCP provided IP

Alternate Configuration has two important informations that kill at least the Segment2 statement:

Automatic private IP address which means APIPA
User configured which means Alternate Configuration

So, User configured will be used and you will have 172.16.0.10 for that Segment2.
The Ipaddress is static so both answer are 172.16.0.10

Segment2 should be 169.254??
172.16.0.10 is not available in segment2

comments.content: There is no dhcp so the address cant be 169. This address appears only when the dhcp cant be reached

discussion.content:
Alternative configuration is possible Only when IP adress is configured as automatic (DHCP).
If you configure an IP amnually, "alternitave Configuration " tab doesn't appear. In our Case, we have an automatic configuration , so computer whill first try to contact a DHCP server. If these is no DHCP on the segment, or if DHCP not responding, alternative configuration will take place. SO answer are correct.

question is asking which IP address should be identified when connecting to the segment. If segment also means subnet then I would say 172.16.0.58 would need to be the identity to be able to connect to 172.16.0.0 subnet.

Also to be able to connect to the 192.168.1.0 subnet, the identity would need to be a 192.168.1.X address

comments.content: But there was said that computer already has static IP address(172.16.0.10).

discussion.content:
You get an apipa adres on segment 1 because of duplicate ip.
Segment 2 just gets the IP 172.16.0.10 as it is static assigned.

comments.content: it doesn't say 10 is already in use. if it is already in use, the PC can not have any IP address because it's duplicated. but in Answer, we don't have option like `can not have network` something like this. therefore it will be assigning 10

adding to my comment, if you give static IP and IP is already assigned for something else, it will be CONFLICTING and we should give it either another static IP or change to DHCP client or you should exclude the IP from DHCP.
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/topic/fix-duplicate-ip-address-conflicts-on-a-dhcp-network-d68499da-69a3-da3b-4630-d17e502adf50

I was wrong. It is not static IP. It is alternate IP
Answer is correct
In the first segment, the first free address is .58 which suggests .10 is already in use.
Why? Where you see that 172.16.0.10 is already used?
Why? Maybe second? Second segment don't have DHCP.
Second segment gives 169.254! 172.16.0.10 can't be enforced in a 192.168.1.0/24 VLAN.

no, if you have an alternative configuration, it will be applied if :
 - DHCP not reponded
- No DHCP configured

discussion.content:
that is not correct for the first
is take a 169.254 address
